author: By The Associated Press
title: Canada Will Not Send Teams to Tokyo in 2020
description: The nation’s Olympic committees called for the Games to be postponed a year for safety precautions amid the coronavirus pandemic.
content: TORONTO — The Canadian Olympic Committee said it would not send athletes to the Tokyo Games this summer and called for them to be postponed for a year, becoming the first country to threaten such a move in the face of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Freud’ and ‘Ghost World’
description: Sigmund Freud is a crime fighter in the new series on Netflix. And a documentary about Robert Crumb by Terry Zwigoff arrives on the Criterion Channel.
content: FREUD Stream on Netflix. There is plenty of dramatic material to be found in the life story of Sigmund Freud. He successfully pioneered the theory and practice of psychoanalysis despite widespread resistance from his colleagues in the medical community and pervasive anti-Semitic prejudice. He escaped the Nazis after Austria was annexed by Germany. And he battled cancer for the last decades of his life. But in this new German-language series from Marvin Kren, fiction supplements fact: The young Freud, played by Robert Finster, is an ambitious doctor drawn into a murder investigation alongside a psychic (Ella Rumpf) and a police inspector (Georg Friedrich).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Trump Administration Gives Apple More Tariff Relief
description: Trade officials approved the company’s request to remove tariffs on the Apple Watch.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — U.S. trade officials removed tariffs on the Apple Watch, the latest Apple device to avoid the United States-China trade war that had once looked like a dire threat to the company’s business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Japanese Food From a Swedish Kitchen
description: “The Japanese Table,” a new book by a Swedish cook smitten with Japan, offers nourishing, small-scale ideas for dinner.
content: Sofia Hellsten is Swedish, but, having lived in Japan, she’s devoted to Japanese food and dining. Her new book explores the simple everyday meals she craves, especially when not in Japan. They’re the sort of nourishing, comforting plates that are easily made and frequently feature vegetables. They’re also enjoyable to serve one or two but no more than four: perfect for troubled times in sequestered households. It’s hard to resist rice, egg and scallions in a soft, single-serving porridge; tamago omelet as egg salad in a sandwich, with miso mayonnaise; silky eggplant with miso; cod with sweet miso that might have been the ur-black cod recipe made famous by Nobu; and somen noodles in a well-seasoned dashi broth. The book does a fine job of explaining Japanese green teas, and there’s a pantry list of staples, most of which are sold online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Add a Sprinkle to Breakfast
description: Lil Bucks, a sprouted buckwheat snack, adds a touch of flavor to granola, yogurt or salads.
content: There’s nothing new about buckwheat, a seed (not really a grain) that’s most comfortable growing in cooler and high-altitude climates worldwide. But the form in which Emily Griffith is selling them is innovative. While living in Australia, she discovered sprouted buckwheat and created Lil Bucks, a company to make and sell the crunchy, earthy-tasting seeds. You can add them to granola, sprinkle them on salad, dust them over yogurt and so forth. Like so much these days, they’re billed as a “superfood,” but the real benefit is their fiber (5 grams in a quarter-cup), protein (6 grams in a quarter-cup), their nice texture and alluring flavor. In addition to plain, they also come flavored with matcha or cacao, neither of which add much in my view. Chunky clusters with other seeds and seasoned with chocolate or turmeric-lemon myrtle are for snacking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: The View From Your Window
description: Life has changed in big ways and small for our On Politics readers from around the world.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and John Williams
title: Woody Allen’s Memoir Is Published
description: Arcade Publishing released “Apropos of Nothing” on Monday. The book had ignited a backlash earlier this month, after its original publisher, Hachette, canceled its plans to release the book.
content: Before it had even been released, Woody Allen’s new autobiography, “Apropos of Nothing,” ignited a ferocious backlash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iliana Magra
title: Alex Salmond, Scotland’s Ex-First Minister, Cleared of Sexual Assault
description: A jury found Mr. Salmond, who led the push for independence in a 2014 referendum, not guilty of attempted rape and sexual assault.
content: Alex Salmond, the former first minister of Scotland, was acquitted on Monday of sexual offenses that involved accusations from nine women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: In Daily Coronavirus Briefing, Trump Tries to Redefine Himself
description: The briefing has given him a unique perch from which he can talk about the pandemic and try to project leadership after initially minimizing it. But that’s not always what he has done.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s campaign rallies have been canceled for the foreseeable future. His noisy back-and-forths with reporters on the South Lawn, half drowned out by the whir of Marine One behind him, have also disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: These Doctors Have Specialties. Fighting Coronavirus Wasn’t One of Them.
description: The pandemic’s spread is creating new challenges for doctors who usually care primarily for patients with particular medical needs.
content: Dr. Scott Isaacs has worked as an endocrinologist for more than two decades, focused on the medical needs of adults with diabetes in the Atlanta area. He never expected to be serving on the front lines of a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: New York Philharmonic Cancels Season Because of Coronavirus
description: The orchestra is anticipating a loss of $10 million and said its endowment had declined by about 14 percent.
content: The New York Philharmonic canceled the remainder of its season on Monday, bowing to the reality that the coronavirus pandemic will silence large-scale performances in the city for months to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: 1,000 Inmates Will Be Released From N.J. Jails to Curb Coronavirus Risk
description: No other state is thought to have taken such sweeping action to reduce its jail population in response to the pandemic.
content: New Jersey will release as many as 1,000 people from its jails in what is believed to be the nation’s broadest effort to address the risks of the highly contagious coronavirus spreading among the incarcerated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Minzayar Oo
title: The ‘Niqab Squad’ Wants Women To Be Seen Differently
description: A movement of Indonesian women promotes the niqab veil as a way to get closer to heaven and avoid sexual harassment. Others fear it reflects growing extremism.
content: TEMBORO, Indonesia — Only the rider’s eyes were visible from behind her black face veil. With a bow in her left hand and an arrow in her right, she cantered her horse toward a target, aimed quickly and let fly. The arrow struck home with a resounding pop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Tiffany Hsu
title: Small Businesses Seek a Crisis Lifeline Beyond Loans
description: Many owners fear taking on debt they are not sure they can repay and are looking to the federal government for more than low-interest disaster loans.
content: As small businesses such as restaurants, bars, gyms and hair salons are forced by the coronavirus pandemic to go dark and lay off millions of employees, frantic owners are desperate for government aid to help them salvage enterprises that can’t survive for long without customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Boris Stankovic, Who Paved Way for N.B.A.’s ‘Dream Team,’ Dies at 94
description: As the longtime head of FIBA, the international game’s governing body, he successfully lobbied to let pros play in the Olympics.
content: Boris Stankovic, the longtime head of basketball’s worldwide governing body and a driving force in the fight to allow N.B.A. players to participate in the Olympics, died on Friday in Belgrade, Serbia. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: As Fox News Played Down the Coronavirus, Its Chief Protected Himself
description: The cancellation of an 89th birthday party for Rupert Murdoch highlights a disconnect between his family’s behavior and statements made on air by some Fox commentators.
content: If you were watching some of the commentators on Fox News and Fox Business in the first 10 days of March, you wouldn’t have been too worried about the coronavirus — it would be no worse than the flu, and the real story was the “coronavirus impeachment scam.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Aurlus Mabele, Congolese King of Soukous Music, Dies at 66
description: His up-tempo hits and high-wattage performances were highlighted by spectacular dance moves. He contracted the coronavirus and died in Paris.
content: Aurlus Mabele, the Congolese singer who was called “the king of soukous,” the energetic dance hall music that blends traditional African and Caribbean rhythms with pop and soul, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Goodnough, Reed Abelson, Margot Sanger-Katz and Sarah Kliff
title: Obamacare Turns 10 Today. Here’s a Look at What Works and Doesn’t.
description: With the coronavirus, a new Supreme Court case and a blistering election debate, the Affordable Care Act is facing challenges as never before. We looked at how it’s held up to its  promise.
content: A pandemic. A Supreme Court challenge (again). A presidential election campaign — this time with attacks from the left as well as the right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Back at Work but Not on the Bench, Supreme Court Issues 3 Major Opinions
description: The court ruled in cases on the insanity defense, race discrimination and copyright infringement.
content: WASHINGTON — In a series of decisions, the Supreme Court on Monday ruled that states may abolish a common form of the insanity defense, that an entrepreneur suing Comcast for race discrimination must meet a demanding standard and that states are immune from claims of copyright infringement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Eric Weissberg, ‘Dueling Banjos’ Musician, Dies at 80
description: His melodic banjo work on a 1973 hit single (heard in the movie “Deliverance”) helped usher bluegrass music into the cultural mainstream.
content: Eric Weissberg, a gifted multi-instrumentalist whose melodic banjo work on the 1973 hit single “Dueling Banjos” helped bring bluegrass music into the cultural mainstream, died on Sunday in a nursing home near Detroit. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller, Tim Arango and Jo Becker
title: As Coronavirus Cases Add Up, California Frantically Counts Tests, Beds and Masks
description: Across a state with many large biotechnology companies, the promise of widespread access to testing for the coronavirus has not materialized.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Wildfires, earthquakes, mudslides. California knows disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Heartburn Drugs Tied to Bone Fractures in Children
description: Proton pump inhibitors are sometimes needed in children with reflux, but parents should be aware they may increase the risk of fractures.
content: Proton pump inhibitors — the widely used heartburn drugs — may slightly increase the risk for bone fractures in children, a new study suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus in N.Y.C.: The Latest
description: Increased testing is revealing how quickly the coronavirus has spread in the state.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: The word AGITA has appeared in the New York Times Crossword 17 times since its debut in 1994, yet it was the entry that most of our solvers missed in the March 16 puzzle by the constructor Gary Cee. It’s enough to give a person heartburn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Will Disabled People Be at a Disadvantage for Scarce Coronavirus Treatment?
description: Advocates in Washington State fear that people who are disabled could be at higher risk of death when doctors and hospitals make end-of-life triage decisions.
content: SEATTLE — Groups representing people with disabilities on Monday challenged a plan that would guide hospitals in Washington State dealing with the coronavirus in the event that they do not have enough lifesaving resources for all the patients who need them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Selvaratnam
title: Where Can Domestic Violence Victims Turn During Covid-19?
description: Self-isolation during the pandemic can be dangerous for those in abusive relationships. Resources are limited, but there are options.
content: The most dangerous place in the world for a woman is her own home. According to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence, intimate partner violence affects millions of women every year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: We All Hate Bailouts, but We Need Them
description: To save American jobs, we need to save American businesses.
content: Here we go again. With business activity having declined precipitously, bailouts of troubled companies are appropriately back on the table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Food, a Basic Pleasure, Is Suddenly Fraught’
description: In this lesson, you will consider how this crisis has affected food and food rituals for people, families and communities, then consider practical things you can do to help.
content: Featured Article: “Food, a Basic Pleasure, Is Suddenly Fraught,” by Kim Severson and Julia Moskin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1 Million Homes in California
description: A bungalow with a guesthouse and converted garage in San Luis Obispo, a grand Victorian in Sacramento and an Edwardian home in Berkeley.
content: When the owner, an architectural and interior designer, bought this house in 2014, it was a bare-bones 1930s bungalow with a small detached garage. In the last five years, he completely transformed the property, adding a brand-new lofted studio behind the house and turning the garage into an indoor-outdoor dining room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Joe Ward
title: As I.O.C. Deliberates, Track and Field Athletes Want Summer Olympics Postponed
description: The I.O.C. said it would spend the next month examining whether to postpone the Tokyo Games. Nearly 80 percent of track and field athletes say to do it now.
content: In recent days, as leaders of the International Olympic Committee went back and forth with organizers of the Tokyo Games, sponsors, media partners and leaders of international sports federations over whether to postpone the Summer Olympics because of the coronavirus pandemic, athletes around the world tried to jump into a debate they say they have had little role in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ioan Grillo
title: Mexico, the Coronavirus and the Hugging President
description: Mr. López Obrador deserves to be strongly criticized, but Mexicans will have to stand together to get through coronavirus.
content: MEXICO CITY — On March 4, a few days after the first coronavirus case was discovered here, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador was asked about the infection at his daily news conference. “With the coronavirus, this idea that you can’t hug,” the president said. “You have to hug. Nothing happens.” He crossed his arms and hugged himself, a signature gesture that he uses to show him hugging the Mexican people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Japanese Food From a Swedish Kitchen
description: “The Japanese Table,” a new book by a Swedish cook smitten with Japan, offers nourishing, small-scale ideas for dinner.
content: Sofia Hellsten is Swedish, but, having lived in Japan, she’s devoted to Japanese food and dining. Her new book explores the simple everyday meals she craves, especially when not in Japan. They’re the sort of nourishing, comforting plates that are easily made and frequently feature vegetables. The book does a fine job of explaining Japanese green teas, and there’s a pantry list of staples, most of which are sold online.

title: In Daily Coronavirus Briefing, Trump Tries to Redefine Himself
description: The briefing has given him a unique perch from which he can talk about the pandemic and try to project leadership after initially minimizing it. But that’s not always what he has done.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s campaign rallies have been canceled for the foreseeable future. His noisy back-and-forths with reporters on the South Lawn, half drowned out by the whir of Marine One behind him, have also disappeared.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Fox News Played Down the Coronavirus, Its Chief Protected Himself
description: The cancellation of an 89th birthday party for Rupert Murdoch highlights a disconnect between his family’s behavior and statements made on air by some Fox commentators.

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Aurlus Mabele, Congolese King of Soukous Music, Dies at 66
description: His up-tempo hits and high-wattage performances were highlighted by spectacular dance moves. He contracted the coronavirus and died in Paris.
content: Aurlus Mabele, the Congolese singer who was called “the king of soukous,” the energetic dance hall music that blends traditional African and Caribbean rhythms with pop and soul, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher and Choe Sang-Hun
title: How South Korea Flattened the Curve
description: The country showed that it is possible to contain the coronavirus without shutting down the economy, but experts are unsure whether its lessons can work abroad.
content: No matter how you look at the numbers, one country stands out from the rest: South Korea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: Danai Gurira Was ‘Amazed’ by Sunday’s ‘The Walking Dead’
description: The actress, who stars as Michonne on the zombie thriller, discussed this week’s episode and the future of her character.
content: This interview includes spoilers for Sunday night’s episode of “The Walking Dead.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: From White Gloves to Latex, the Doormen of New York
description: Intercepting extra deliveries, swabbing the elevator buttons with Lysol and soothing the nervous rich.
content: They are the white-gloved sentries, standing guard at New York City’s better addresses, so signature a feature of life here that we tend to forget that in other metropolitan centers like Paris, London, Chicago or Boston uniformed doormen (and, less often, women) barely exist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Jeremy Marre, Documentarian of World Music, Is Dead at 76
description: With a minimal camera and sound crew, Mr. Marre traveled the world to film music and musicians on home turf that was often gritty and unglamorous.
content: Jeremy Marre, an English filmmaker who documented music from across the world with hardheaded clarity, died on March 15 at a hospital in London, where he had lived. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Coronavirus Has Opened the Corporate Email Floodgates
description: The email deluge raises questions about marketing practices as nonessential businesses closed shops and storefronts amid the spread of the new coronavirus.
content: Maybe it was that one store where you shopped while on vacation a few years ago, or perhaps that online service that you used just last week, but it’s all the same message: Businesses have flooded everyone on their email lists with coronavirus updates, tips on staying healthy and words of encouragement — much to people’s dismay.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1 Million in California
description: A bungalow with a guesthouse and converted garage in San Luis Obispo, a grand Victorian in Sacramento and an Edwardian home in Berkeley.
content: A bungalow with a guesthouse and converted garage in San Luis Obispo, a grand Victorian in Sacramento and an Edwardian home in Berkeley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Throw Away One Worry This Week
description: We have enough on our plates right now.
content: Yesterday I opened my cupboard and stared at a pair of garish, orange plastic cups. I use these cups to serve my children milk, and as recently as last week, I would look at them and think: I really should throw these out. I don’t even remember where they came from, and they’re probably leeching all sorts of unpronounceable toxins into my kids’ bloodstreams every time they take a sip — which I know from our own coverage of plastics!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: Biden Addresses a Visibility Question: ‘How Do We Get More of You?’
description: As President Trump appears at daily briefings, the Democratic front-runner faces the challenge of raising his profile in a presidential race that has moved almost entirely into the digital realm.
content: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., the likely Democratic nominee against President Trump in this year’s general election, was asked a question during a virtual fund-raiser on Sunday that reflected a challenge looming over his campaign as the coronavirus outbreak intensifies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penina Krieger and Abby Goodnough
title: Medical Students, Sidelined for Now, Find New Ways to Fight Coronavirus
description: After medical schools ended contact with patients, disappointed students organized to collect masks, work at call centers and offer child care to health workers.
content: As hospitals around the United States brace for an ongoing surge in coronavirus cases, one question they are grappling with is whether medical students should be deployed to help care for patients infected with the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: What Counts as an ‘Essential Business’?
description: Monday: Californians are navigating a new reality and finding that “stay at home” isn’t a black-and-white order.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Helvarg
title: We Need a Unified Military Command for Disaster Response
description: The pandemic is only one of many potential disasters that will require unity of action among the armed services.
content: President Trump has finally called in the military in the nation’s war against the coronavirus. But precious time was lost in the weeks since he was warned about the dangers the virus poses. We need to make sure that doesn’t happen again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Meal Kits From the Chef Dan Barber
description: The meals, which serve two to four, are available next week at Blue Hill at Stone Barns.
content: Like a number of other chefs and restaurants, Dan Barber, the chef and an owner of Blue Hill in Manhattan, and Blue Hill at Stone Barns in Westchester County, is assembling market boxes for pickup. Each will contain ingredients and cooking instructions for a dish that will serve two to four people. Though the ingredients will vary daily, you can count on a rich broth as one of the components, along with fresh and fermented vegetables, meats, eggs and a flatbread made with freshly milled flour. They are meant to keep the restaurant staff and local farmers employed. The ingredients and recipe will change weekly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Herrera
title: 9 Delightful Articles to Help You Get Through This Week
description: We’re all just trying to do our best now. These articles might help a little.
content: What a year this month has been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Bonisteel
title: The Best Canned Tomatoes
description: In a taste test conducted by Wirecutter and NYT Cooking, two American brands came out on top.
content: At this moment, as you’re holed up at home, the best canned tomatoes are the ones you’ll grab from your cabinet to make dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: What Counts as an ‘Essential Business’?
description: Monday: Californians are navigating a new reality and finding that “stay at home” isn’t a black-and-white order.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Pandemic and the Primary
description: How the coronavirus has changed the stakes of the presidential race — and created a crisis candidate.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: Coronavirus Relief, PG&E, Woody Allen: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simran Sethi
title: Why Mundane Moments Truly Matter
description: “How we spend our days is how we spend our lives.”
content: My mother and I have sipped tea with maharanis, swapped stories with Burmese nuns and bumped through the streets of Bangkok on midnight tuk tuks — but the delight we return to, again and again, is the moon. “Go outside and take a look,” she’ll command over text, and I’ll stumble out the door to glimpse at a crescent sliver. We swap cellphone photos of fuzzy white discs that are indistinguishable from the ones that preceded them but offer what feels like newfound delight. Our shared moon: a simple joy that binds us together across years and over continents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Harvey Weinstein Tests Positive for the Coronavirus
description: The film producer, who is serving 23 years for sex crimes, has been isolated from other prisoners but has shown no symptoms.
content: Harvey Weinstein, the disgraced film producer who was convicted of two felony sex crimes in a case that helped start the #MeToo movement, has contracted the coronavirus, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Rand Paul’s Positive Coronavirus Test Sets the (Still Meeting) Senate on Edge
description: The Kentucky Republican’s diagnosis has injected a shot of fear into the Senate as it scrambles to pass a relief package to respond to the pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — In another workplace, in another town, the news that a colleague who, days and even hours before testing positive for the novel coronavirus, had been dining and meeting and working out alongside his co-workers might have spurred some drastic measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Rand Paul’s Positive Coronavirus Test Sets the (Still Meeting) Senate on Edge
description: The Kentucky Republican’s diagnosis has injected a shot of fear into the Senate as it scrambles to pass a relief package to respond to the pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — In another workplace, in another town, the news that a colleague who, days and even hours before testing positive for the novel coronavirus, had been dining and meeting and working out alongside his co-workers might have spurred some drastic measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: U.S. and U.A.E. Troops Hold Major Exercise Amid Virus and Iran Tensions
description: The biennial exercise, called Native Fury, shows the close ties between American forces and the U.A.E.
content: AL-HAMRA MILITARY BASE, United Arab Emirates — U.S. Marines and Emirati forces held a major military exercise Monday that saw forces seize a sprawling model Mideast city, a drill conducted amid tensions with Iran and despite the new coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Take Steps to Counter the Loneliness of Social Distancing
description: Attempts to avoid coronavirus can increase the risk of physical and emotional harm from limited social contact.
content: Two years ago, when Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, the former surgeon general of the United States, started researching his book, “Together: The Healing Power of Human Connection in a Sometimes Lonely World,” he never anticipated how relevant the topic would be now that it is about to be published.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: The Unseen Survivors of Thalidomide Want to Be Heard
description: The U.S. was supposed to have escaped the devastation of a drug that caused birth defects in babies overseas. This is the almost forgotten story of its toll in America.
content: The man on the bus was staring at her. Carolyn Farmer, 17, noticed him as she closed the Leon Uris novel “Exodus” and gathered her things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer and Choe Sang-Hun
title: As Coronavirus Surveillance Escalates, Personal Privacy Plummets
description: Tracking entire populations to combat the pandemic now could open the doors to more invasive forms of government snooping later.
content: In South Korea, government agencies are harnessing surveillance-camera footage, smartphone location data and credit card purchase records to help trace the recent movements of coronavirus patients and establish virus transmission chains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: The Search for E.T. Goes on Hold, for Now
description: A popular screen saver takes a break while its inventors try to digest data that may yet be hiding news of extraterrestrials.
content: One of the great science fiction fantasies of all time — that you might discover aliens texting you from outer space on your computer — is about to take a breather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: When Atlanta Destroyed a Housing Project to Save It
description: The PBS documentary “East Lake Meadows,” from the executive producer Ken Burns, tells a complicated and melancholy story of race and public policy.
content: The makers of “East Lake Meadows: A Public Housing Story” probably would not have chosen to premiere their documentary (Tuesday, on PBS) in the midst of an all-consuming global crisis. But as it turns out, their admirable, melancholy film syncs up well with Covid-19 anxiety — in part as a reminder that for some Americans, social and economic devastation in daily life is a pre-existing condition.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump’s Leadership in the Coronavirus Crisis
description: Readers criticize the president’s daily briefings, attack on a reporter and refusal to use the Defense Production Act.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Apuzzo and Monika Pronczuk
title: Covid-19’s Economic Pain Is Universal. But Relief? Depends on Where You Live.
description: In some countries, workers will have 90 percent of lost wages covered. In others, residents fear eviction. Nation to nation, rescue plans reflect conflicting ideas of government’s role in a crisis.
content: In a Queens apartment, a laid-off busboy has no idea if he will make next month’s rent or feed his family. An out-of-work waitress in Amsterdam, though, can count on the government to cover 90 percent of her wages. As a Malaysian florist anxiously burns through her savings, cafe owners in Brussels receive about $4,300 to make up for lost revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Suderman
title: It’s a Perfect Time to Play Video Games. And You Shouldn’t Feel Bad About It.
description: The longer the coronavirus keeps social life and culture in isolation, the more we’ll need frivolity and escapism.
content: The last time I was unemployed was in the depths of the Great Recession. I had recently moved in with my girlfriend, who suddenly found herself with an out-of-work partner who rarely left the house. But she gave me some surprising advice: Play video games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: Shouting, Finger-Pointing and Threats in a Florida City on Edge
description: A town’s emergency meeting turned into a shouting match and a viral video as tensions over its coronavirus response boiled over.
content: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — They were both yelling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: The Search for E.T. Goes on Hold, for Now
description: A popular screen saver takes a break while its inventors try to digest data that may yet be hiding news of extraterrestrials.
content: One of the great science fiction fantasies of all time — that you might discover aliens texting you from outer space on your computer — is about to take a breather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Take Steps to Counter the Loneliness of Social Distancing
description: Attempts to avoid coronavirus can increase the risk of physical and emotional harm from limited social contact.
content: Two years ago, when Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, the former surgeon general of the United States, started researching his book, “Together: The Healing Power of Human Connection in a Sometimes Lonely World,” he never anticipated how relevant the topic would be now that it is about to be published.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: At a Murder Mystery Weekend, Whodunit? Everyone
description: A critic disguised as an actress who is also a suspect in the death of the Great Merlini. Her team didn’t use “Cats” to break the case, though.
content: Earlier this month, in what already feels like a different world, I found myself onstage, holding a pen I had swiped from the hotel’s reception desk and reciting a garbled version of the dagger speech from “Macbeth.” It felt giddy, hyperreal and a little like a benign version of a nightmare — the kind of nightmare I still have even though I haven’t acted in almost two decades and my professional career, if you want to dignify it that way, lasted months. In the nightmare, I come to in the middle of a play and I don’t know any of my lines. See? Dreams do come true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: Feeling Powerless About Coronavirus? Join a Mutual-Aid Network
description: A quarantine is the perfect time to get (virtually) close to your community.
content: A pandemic is frightening, and isolating. It is psychically frustrating: We need other people now more than ever. At the same time, other people have never been more dangerous to our health. The choice to go outside, even to help others, means assuming risk — for yourself, loved ones and strangers. It’s easy to feel powerless and alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Motoko Rich
title: U.S. Olympic Committee Urges Postponing Summer Games in Tokyo
description: The United States added its voice to growing calls for the Tokyo Games to be rescheduled because of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee is urging that the Summer Olympics in Tokyo be postponed because of the coronavirus pandemic, adding its large and influential voice to a growing chorus of athletes and sports federations objecting to having the Games go on as scheduled in late July and early August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian M. Rosenthal
title: Density Is New York City’s Big ‘Enemy’ in the Coronavirus Fight
description: New York is more crowded than any large city in the country. That helps explain why it is the U.S. epicenter of the outbreak.
content: New York has tried to slow the spread of the coronavirus by closing its schools, shutting down its nonessential businesses and urging its residents to stay home almost around the clock. But it faces a distinct obstacle in trying to stem new cases: its cheek-by-jowl density.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Westworld’ Season 3, Episode 2 Recap: A Band of Thugs
description: Maeve wakes up confused. And able to speak Italian.
content: One of the funniest running jokes in “Westworld” — check that, maybe the only running joke in “Westworld” — is that the hosts are virtually indistinguishable from the guests, and yet the scripted loops in the park are Z-grade genre television. The show hasn’t had the opportunity to return to that joke much recently, save for a version of the saloon heist that played out in Shogun World, but the opening of this week’s episode is clever opportunity to stick a fully woke host in a chintzy, down-the-dial World War II spy thriller.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: March 23, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 23, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 23, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Dining Chairs
description: With so many of us working at the dining table these days, our chairs need to be multifunctional. Here’s how to choose the right ones.
content: With more people spending more time at home these days, dining chairs are getting a workout — as seating for meals, but also as improvised places to sit while working or home schooling.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Will Fill a $4 Trillion Hole in the Economy?
description: In an echo of 2008, partisan wrangling caused a giant stimulus bill to stumble, even as the market plunged and businesses buckled.
content: If you couldn’t join us on Friday for our special conference call about the business and policy implications of the coronavirus pandemic, the recording is here. The response was enormous — more than 4,000 of you signed up to participate — so we couldn’t get to all of the questions. What should we cover in future calls? Let us know. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Scientists Identify 69 Drugs to Test Against the Coronavirus
description: Two dozen of the medicines are already under investigation. Also on the list: chloroquine, a drug used to treat malaria.
content: Nearly 70 drugs and experimental compounds may be effective in treating the coronavirus, a team of researchers reported on Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Remember When Japan Blasted an Asteroid? Here’s What We Learned
description: The Hayabusa2 spacecraft’s explosive encounter reveals that a space rock called Ryugu looks extremely young for its age.
content: In April last year, a Japanese spacecraft launched a strike from above on an asteroid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele and Neil Vigdor
title: Singalongs From Windowsills Lift Spirits During Coronavirus Crisis
description: Following an example set by Europeans who sang from balconies, some homebound Americans are communally belting out tunes from their windows.
content: The idea took root after Jenni Spinner and her wife, Rebecca Kell, watched videos of Europeans, homebound because of the coronavirus, get on their balconies and sing to raise their spirits in the face of crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About the United Kingdom?
description: Can you find the United Kingdom on a map? What else do you know about this European nation with a population of about 67 million people?
content: Can you find the United Kingdom on a map? What else do you know about this European nation with a population of about 67 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Werner Herzog Has Never Thought a Dog Was Cute
description: “I would assign a dog a different word.”
content: “I would assign a dog a different word.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Highly Adaptable Vegetarian Skillet Chili
description: If you have beans and tomatoes, you’re most of the way to this simple meal.
content: Are you ready for another bean dish? I sure am, which is a good thing considering how many kinds of beans I have on hand. (I’m not hoarding; I’m just extremely well stocked.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Logged On From the Laundry Room: How the C.E.O.s of Google, Pfizer and Slack Work From Home
description: As chief executives hunker down during the pandemic, home offices have become corporate headquarters.
content: On Thursday morning, Chuck Robbins, the chief executive of Cisco, signed on to an companywide video conference from his home office in Silicon Valley. The connection was stable, but the quality was not great.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Glass Hotel,’ by Emily St. John Mandel: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “The Glass Hotel,” by Emily St. John Mandel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Romer and Alan M. Garber
title: Will Our Economy Die From Coronavirus?
description: It will if we keep up our current strategy.
content: Covid-19, the most threatening pandemic of the past century, has precipitated both a health crisis and an economic crisis. The strategies that governments have adopted to deal with each crisis separately are contradictory and risk catastrophic, long-term failure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Glass Hotel,’ by Emily St. John Mandel: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “The Glass Hotel,” by Emily St. John Mandel
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: How Trump Is Worsening the Virus Now
description: Medical shortages are his responsibility.
content: At a private New York meeting in October of 1940, William Knudsen made a desperate plea to the automobile industry’s top executives. Knudsen himself had been the president of General Motors until a few months earlier. But he had stepped down to help oversee military production at President Franklin Roosevelt’s request. The position paid $1 a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter and Matthew Goldstein
title: Bankers Pledge Mortgage Help, but Want Billions
description: Millions of borrowers may be unable to make payments on home loans next week. The mortgage industry says it’s willing to help, but needs the government to back it up.
content: In just days, tens of millions of people across the United States will have to make fresh payments on their mortgages. Their lenders have come up with a plan to help borrowers who can’t pay because of the economic fallout from the coronavirus — and they want the federal government to backstop it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Turner
title: The Plastic-Hunting Pirates of the Cornish Coast
description: The Clean Ocean Sailing initiative removes plastic waste from areas of England’s coastline that are inaccessible by foot.
content: The Cornish coast — with its high cliffs and inlets, lining the peninsula that juts out from England’s southwest corner — has a long association with pirates. Its rocky coves, secret anchorages and long winding creeks have historically been a haunting ground for seafaring scoundrels and salty sea dogs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Grim News Blunts Federal Reserve’s Crisis Response
description: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: This briefing is no longer updating. Read the latest developments in the coronavirus outbreak here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Dolnick
title: As Postal Workers Fall Sick, Colleagues Keep Working. And Worrying.
description: The coronavirus has affected about two dozen Postal Service workers around the country, and fear of a greater outbreak grows.
content: Chris Jackson was halfway through his overnight shift sorting the mail for delivery when he and several colleagues were summoned into a windowless conference room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Man Convicted of Trying to Blow Up Oklahoma City Bank Gets 25 Years in Prison
description: Jerry Drake Varnell was arrested in 2017 after a thwarted attempt to blow up a bank in downtown Oklahoma City — a plot similar to one carried out there in 1995.
content: A man who was arrested in 2017 after a thwarted attempt to blow up a bank in downtown Oklahoma City — a plot that echoed the deadly bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building there in 1995 — was sentenced Monday to 25 years in prison, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Royal Ballet and Liam Scarlett Part Ways After an Investigation
description: The choreographer is leaving the company, although a sexual misconduct inquiry found “no matters to pursue” against him.
content: LONDON — The British choreographer Liam Scarlett on Monday left his position as the Royal Ballet’s artist-in-residence, after an investigation into accusations of sexual misconduct with dance students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Nicholas Fandos
title: Top Senate Democrat and Treasury Secretary Say They Are Near a Stimulus Deal
description: Hours after Democrats blocked the nearly $2 trillion package, a marathon set of private negotiations appeared to have yielded important compromises.
content: WASHINGTON — The Treasury secretary and the top Senate Democrat said late Monday that they were on the brink of a deal on a nearly $2 trillion emergency economic aid measure to respond to the coronavirus pandemic, after a marathon day of talks as Democrats demanded stronger protections for workers and restrictions for bailed-out businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: Pursuing an Untold Story of Thalidomide
description: The drug was connected to birth defects in 10,000 babies overseas. But following the trail in the United States was more complicated.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: The Story of Thalidomide in the U.S., Told Through Documents
description: A trove of archival records shows how in the early 1960s the Food and Drug Administration investigated the use of a drug that caused severe birth defects.
content: In July 1962, the Food and Drug Administration sent an urgent message to its field offices with an assignment it said was “one of the most important we have had in a long time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: Thalidomide Use Did Happen Here, These Americans Say
description: They believe they were harmed in the thalidomide crisis of the 1950s and 1960s.
content: Even though thalidomide did not reach American pharmacy shelves, the drug was distributed to as many as 20,000 patients through two clinical trials run by American companies that were testing it for use in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: When Coronavirus Closes Your Lab, Can Science Go On?
description: Plenty of work can be done from home, but the pandemic is forcing some parts of the scientific process to be put on the shelf.
content: In recent weeks, coronavirus led to the shutdown of many university campuses and other institutions for research and learning in the United States and around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Marc Tracy
title: Local News Outlets Dealt a Crippling Blow by This Biggest of Stories
description: Layoffs. Canceled print editions. Weekly papers and small dailies across the country face peril as the coronavirus cuts off ads and live events.
content: Once the Chocolate Pig closed, the paper was in trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis
title: PG&E Will Plead Guilty to Involuntary Manslaughter in Camp Fire
description: The California utility faced felony charges in connection with a 2018 wildfire that killed more than 80 people.
content: Pacific Gas & Electric, California’s largest utility, said Monday that it had agreed to plead guilty to involuntary manslaughter in connection with the Camp Fire, the state’s deadliest wildfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose and Gabriel J.X. Dance
title: The Coronavirus Revives Facebook as a News Powerhouse
description: More than half of all news consumption on Facebook in America is about the virus, according to an internal report.
content: Until recently, Facebook could feel at times like the virtual equivalent of a sleepy bingo parlor — an outmoded gathering place populated mainly by retirees looking for conversation and cheap fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley McChrystal and Chris Fussell
title: What 9/11 Taught Us About Leadership in a Crisis
description: Sept. 11 changed how U.S. Special Forces operated — and offers lessons for today’s leaders.
content: On Sept. 11, 2001, the job of every leader in the U.S. Special Operations community changed. In the ensuing years of fighting a highly complex, networked enemy, we redesigned how our organization communicated, shared information, made decisions and, most critically, maintained a cohesive culture while operating in almost every corner of the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: After the Fire, a Chinatown Museum Sifts Through What Survived
description: Families are celebrating hundreds of boxes of heirlooms that were unloaded from the scorched interior of 70 Mulberry Street.
content: When a fire ripped through the upper floors of the red brick building that held the archives of the Museum of Chinese in America, the staff thought that all was lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Whatever It Takes: How the Fed Aims to Rescue the Economy
description: The central bank is using tactics from the last financial crisis and deploying new ones to keep money flowing. Here are the basics.
content: The Federal Reserve on Monday pledged to do, in essence, whatever it takes to keep the economy from collapsing under the weight of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Mitch, Please!’ Tours Kentucky and Roasts a Senator
description: Matt Jones drove through each of his state’s 120 counties to understand why Mitch McConnell polls so poorly there yet is serving his sixth full term in the Senate.
content: In times of national crisis, it’s important to put past differences behind us. On the other hand, here’s a new book that trolls Mitch McConnell for 500 pages. Can’t a person have a look?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: ‘One Day at a Time’ Still Standing and Being Counted
description: The former Netflix sitcom about a Cuban-American family returns on Pop TV, slightly shorter but big on laughs and purpose.
content: “One Day at a Time” recently escaped a brush with cancellation, so it’s appropriate that the new season begins with a head count to make sure that everyone’s OK.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: After the Fire, a Chinatown Museum Sifts Through What Survived
description: Families are celebrating hundreds of boxes of heirlooms that were unloaded from the scorched interior of 70 Mulberry Street.
content: When a fire ripped through the upper floors of the red brick building that held the archives of the Museum of Chinese in America, the staff thought that all was lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: 20-Somethings Now Realizing That They Can Get Coronavirus, Too
description: More than 40 percent of those who have tested positive for the virus in New York City are between the ages of 18 and 44.
content: Marissa Crider set up strict house rules after recently taking in a third roommate in her apartment in Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Mitch, Please!’ Tours Kentucky and Roasts a Senator
description: Matt Jones drove through each of his state’s 120 counties to understand why Mitch McConnell polls so poorly there yet is serving his sixth full term in the Senate.
content: In times of national crisis, it’s important to put past differences behind us. On the other hand, here’s a new book that trolls Mitch McConnell for 500 pages. Can’t a person have a look?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan and Alexander Burns
title: Joe Biden Is Trying to Be Heard on the Virus. Can He Break Through?
description: As President Trump holds daily briefings, Mr. Biden has kept a low profile, worrying Democrats who feel the president needs to be challenged more robustly.
content: With President Trump providing daily televised briefings and governors like Andrew M. Cuomo emerging as national leaders during the coronavirus pandemic, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is still grappling with how to position himself as a prominent voice on a crisis that is pushing traditional politics to the background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Rosie O’Donnell Returns, With Guests in the Basement and the Bathtub
description: For over three hours online Sunday night, the Broadway superfan schmoozed, fund-raised and gave stars a chance to share their music.
content: A lot happened during the just-this-once edition of “The Rosie O’Donnell Show” that streamed live Sunday night — that would be expected with an event lasting three and a half hours. But it will be hard to top Adrienne Warren, the star of “Tina: The Tina Turner Musical,” singing “Simply the Best” in a bathtub, clad in a bathing suit worthy of a 1970s Bond girl. At the end of the song, she whipped out a tiny toy saxophone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Britain Placed Under a Virtual Lockdown by Boris Johnson
description: The prime minister closed all nonessential shops, banning meetings of more than two people and requiring people to stay in their homes, except for trips for food or medicine.
content: LONDON — Facing a growing storm of criticism about his laissez-faire response to the fast-spreading coronavirus, Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced on Monday that he would place Britain under a virtual lockdown, closing all nonessential shops, banning meetings of more than two people, and requiring people to stay in their homes, except for trips for food or medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson and Kristin Hussey
title: Party Zero: How a Soirée in Connecticut Became a ‘Super Spreader’
description: About 50 people gathered this month for a party in the upscale suburb of Westport, then scattered across the region and the world, taking the coronavirus with them.
content: About 50 guests gathered on March 5 at a home in the stately suburb of Westport, Conn., to toast the hostess on her 40th birthday and greet old friends, including one visiting from South Africa. They shared reminiscences, a lavish buffet and, unknown to anyone, the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: Texas and Ohio Include Abortion as Medical Procedures That Must Be Delayed
description: The moves by the states set off a new front in the political fight over abortion during the coronavirus pandemic.
content: Texas and Ohio have included abortions among the nonessential surgeries and medical procedures that they are requiring to be delayed, setting off a new front in the fight over abortion rights in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Suddenly, the Lowly Bean Is a Coveted Pantry Item
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 23, 2020.
content: “No one ever cares about beans at all. It’s just shocking. I used to be the loneliest man at the farmer’s market.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: quid pro quo
description: This term has appeared in 376 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.

title: Reporting From a Center of the Coronavirus Outbreak
description: Mike Baker is the Seattle bureau chief for The Times. We asked him what it’s like reporting from the state with one of the deadliest caseloads in America.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: On Politics: Where’s the Relief?
description: Senate wrangling and presidential promises: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: A medical official at the White House took the temperature of a member of the news media in the White House briefing room on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barbara Marcolini and Robin Stein
title: ‘Brace Yourself’: How Doctors in Italy Responded to Coronavirus
description: Officials in the U.S. and elsewhere fear they’ll face a coronavirus scenario similar to Italy’s soon. Three doctors and a nurse in Lombardy, the region hit hardest by the virus, described what they faced and offered advice to those awaiting the storm.
content: Officials in the U.S. and elsewhere fear they’ll face a coronavirus scenario similar to Italy’s soon. Three doctors and a nurse in Lombardy, the region hit hardest by the virus, described what they faced and offered advice to those awaiting the storm.

title: Coronavirus, Senate, Summer Olympics: Your Monday Briefing

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Coronavirus Complicates Home Buying and Mortgage Refinancing
description: As county records office around the country shutdown, title searches and deed filings will grind to a halt.
content: The coronavirus has snarled many spring home-buying plans, as apartment buildings ban open houses, real estate agents shutter brokerages and quarantines make it tough to even step outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What Are You Reading, Watching, Listening To, Playing and Cooking? A Place for Recommendations
description: What’s helping right now? What can you recommend to other teenagers?
content: What’s working for you right now? Have you been able to distract yourself with a movie? Find wisdom in a book? Lose yourself playing a game? Learn — or laugh — thanks to a podcast? Have fun at a digital gathering? Whether you have one idea or many, tell us in the comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Cook With Confidence
description: You don’t have to have all the ingredients to follow a recipe, or to make a great meal. Make the recipe your own.
content: Good morning. Took a drive with a kid and a dog on Sunday morning, out to where the people drop away and the oystercatchers skim the shoreline, to where it’s quiet but for wind through the spartina, and the slap of the bay against the peat. We walked in companionable silence. I thought about how you’re doing, cooking every day for the first time in ages if ever, and running into recipes that may call for things like escarole and preserved lemons, crème fraîche, maple syrup, Champagne vinegar. Maybe you don’t have those ingredients. Maybe that freaks you out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: SoftBank Says It Will Sell $41 Billion in Assets to Buy Back Shares
description: The Japanese conglomerate has bet heavily on companies that are likely to take a significant financial hit from the coronavirus outbreak.
content: TOKYO — SoftBank, operator of the world’s largest tech fund, said on Monday that it would sell as much as $41 billion in assets as it seeks to vacuum up its own shares, which have dropped precipitously in the last month amid investor concerns about the coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaclyn Peiser
title: The Medical ID Bracelet That Doesn’t Look Like One
description: An ID can be crucial in a medical crisis, and it doesn’t have to be something you want to hide.
content: In times of uncertainty, people turn to many places for peace of mind: cooking, exercising, reading the news, multiperson video chats and other virtual gatherings, fresh air. When that uncertainty stems from a global pandemic, the actions we take to protect our bodies and minds may also include washing our hands, social distancing and working from home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ari Ne'eman
title: ‘I Will Not Apologize for My Needs’
description: Even in a crisis, doctors should not abandon the principle of nondiscrimination.
content: Times of crisis ask us who we are as a country. As hospitals prepare for shortages in ventilators and other scarce medical resources, many people with disabilities are worried about the answer to that question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lori Gottlieb
title: Grieving the Losses of Coronavirus
description: In addition to the tragic losses of life and health and jobs we are grieving the losses of weddings, sports and the ability to buy eggs or get a haircut.
content: When it comes to the coronavirus outbreak, what’s the word related to mental health that you hear most? If you said “anxiety,” you’re not alone. But if you were to sit (virtually, of course) in a therapist’s office like mine or any of my colleagues’, what you might hear just as often is the word “loss.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Lil Uzi Vert Holds at No. 1, and Streaming Habits Are Shifting
description: During the coronavirus crisis, listeners are turning to older songs and family music, but the biggest new releases are still going strong.
content: During the coronavirus pandemic, millions of people are turning to streaming music services for entertainment and distraction — but how are streaming numbers holding up?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman and Sapna Maheshwari
title: ‘Our Industry Will Fail’: Retail Leaders Ask for Emergency Aid
description: Predicting millions of job losses in retail, an industry presses for federal money to save the retail clothing industries.
content: Over the past five days, executives from the largest American clothing brands and department stores have been engaged in urgent late-night phone calls and marathon video conferences in which they game out scenarios for their future in a world with a coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar and Katherine Schulten
title: An Argumentative-Writing Unit for Students Doing Remote Learning
description: Suggestions for self-guided activities that can help students practice making claims and supporting them with evidence.
content: Note to Teachers: Here is a PDF teacher’s guide for using this unit with students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: South Korea’s Method, Coronavirus Treatment, SoftBank: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Jack Nicas, Steve Lohr and Mike Isaac
title: Big Tech Could Emerge From Coronavirus Crisis Stronger Than Ever
description: Amazon is hiring aggressively to meet customer demand. Traffic has soared on Facebook and YouTube. And cloud computing has become essential to home workers.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — While the rest of the economy is tanking from the crippling impact of the coronavirus, business at the biggest technology companies is holding steady — even thriving.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Wrong Way to Fight Coronavirus
description: Yale health experts take strong issue with an Op-Ed essay that suggested letting the virus run its course. Also: Senator Rand Paul’s error; public works projects; lagging on disability rights.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Ana Swanson
title: The U.S. Needs China’s Masks, as Acrimony Grows
description: Beijing has signaled a willingness to supply the U.S. as its outbreak spreads. Increasingly harsh language and logistical issues could make it difficult to reach deals.
content: SHANGHAI — American front-line medical personnel are running desperately short of masks and protective equipment as they battle the coronavirus outbreak. China, already the world’s largest producer of such gear by far, has ramped up factory output and is now signaling that it wants to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz
title: Ex-Field Organizers Sue Bloomberg Campaign, Claiming They Were Misled
description: Former campaign workers for Michael Bloomberg filed two proposed class-action lawsuits on Monday, arguing they and thousands of others were tricked into taking their jobs and are owed overtime pay.
content: Former field organizers for Michael R. Bloomberg filed two proposed class-action lawsuits against his presidential campaign Monday, arguing that they and thousands of others laid off this month had been tricked into taking jobs they were told would last until November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Lil Uzi Vert, a Hip-Hop Star Beyond Gatekeepers
description: The rapper’s long-awaited second studio album, “Eternal Atake,” and the deluxe version that followed provide rowdy thrills.
content: Lil Uzi Vert, perhaps the defining rap star of the past few years, is a cipher, a whirlwind, an alien. An accident of history. A chemical recombination of what hip-hop success sounds, looks and, maybe most importantly, feels like in an era in which the old gatekeepers have been all but sidelined. Breakout hits? One or two. Radio? Not so much. Promotional dog-and-pony show? As if.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz and Reed Abelson
title: Eleven States Now Letting Uninsured Sign Up for Obamacare
description: More coronavirus care will be covered in many states. Federal officials are considering similar action for the state markets they run.
content: Eleven states and the District of Columbia have opened enrollment under the Affordable Care Act to allow laid-off workers to get subsidized health insurance, and the Trump administration, which has been gunning to repeal the law, is considering opening the federal exchange to new customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Kantor
title: Coronavirus Makes Daily Life Confounding. Here Are Some Answers.
description: Welcome to Dilemmas, where we find solutions to your toughest quandaries.
content: How to stay safe. How to protect others. How much risk to take when the smallest act can be a risk: touching a doorknob, buying milk. Whether or not the virus has reached your neighborhood, what’s swept into everyone’s lives is a set of confounding dilemmas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise and Richard A. Oppel Jr
title: Spit On, Yelled At, Attacked: Chinese-Americans Fear for Their Safety
description: As bigots blame them for the coronavirus and President Trump labels it the “Chinese virus,” many Chinese-Americans say they are terrified of what could come next.
content: WASHINGTON — Yuanyuan Zhu was walking to her gym in San Francisco on March 9, thinking the workout could be her last for a while, when she noticed that a man was shouting at her. He was yelling an expletive about China. Then a bus passed, she recalled, and he screamed after it, “Run them over.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: Coronavirus Patients in Limbo as Gilead Suspends Emergency Drug Access
description: The company says it will switch to a broader approach for its experimental drug, remdesivir. But it was overwhelmed by demand for a potential treatment promoted by President Trump.
content: Overwhelmed by demand for an experimental treatment for coronavirus, the drug maker Gilead abruptly shut down its emergency access program, leaving doctors and families scrambling for answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Mozambique Insurgents Stage Attacks Near Big Gas Projects
description: Government troops were fighting Islamist fighters amid concern that the country’s growing gas industry may be under threat.
content: MAPUTO — Mozambican troops battled Islamist insurgents in a northern town on Monday close to billion-dollar gas projects being developed by Exxon Mobil and Total, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus ‘Attack Rate’ in N.Y. Concerns White House
description: The New York City region is now an epicenter of the pandemic.
content: The White House’s coronavirus response coordinator offered a grim assessment of the virus’s assault on the New York metropolitan area Monday evening: She said that nearly 1 in 1,000 people in the region have contracted the virus, an “attack rate” five times that of other areas.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 158 Million Americans Told to Stay Home, but Trump Pledges to Keep It Short
description: The White House warned of an alarming spread in New York City, but the president said “our country wasn’t built to be shut down.”
content: This briefing is no longer updating. You can find the latest coronavirus news here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Webinar Wednesdays: Opportunities for Teachers and Parents on Remote Learning With The Times
description: As part of our response to Covid-19 and school closings, we are hosting a series of webinars on teaching and learning with Times resources and our own collection of activities for students.
content: Last week we hosted two webinars for teachers, librarians and parents about how to use The Learning Network for remote learning. Over 500 people attended. And at the end of the sessions, when we asked participants what else we could do to help educators during these uncertain times, they responded: offer more virtual professional development opportunities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Democratic Convention Planners Look at Contingency Options
description: The coronavirus crisis has created uncertainty about whether the gathering, scheduled for mid-July in Milwaukee, can still take place.
content: WASHINGTON — Planners for the Democratic National Convention are looking at “contingency options” in case the mid-July gathering in Milwaukee can’t take place because of the coronavirus, officials said on Monday for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Lara Jakes
title: Pompeo Cuts $1 Billion in Afghan Aid as 2 Leaders Reject Push for Unity
description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo failed to persuade rival Afghan leaders to support a unified government, which American diplomats consider crucial to preventing peace negotiations from falling apart.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The State Department said it was cutting $1 billion in aid to Afghanistan this year, and potentially another $1 billion in 2021, after Secretary of State Mike Pompeo failed to persuade rival Afghan leaders in a meeting on Monday in Kabul to support a unified government, which American diplomats consider crucial to preventing peace negotiations from falling apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Handy Measure
description: These shot glasses let you mete out precious liquors, and come in handy for baking projects.
content: You need a drink, but you — not some mixologist — are in charge. Though professionals prefer little metal measuring containers, this set of one-and-a-half ounce glass ones, with markings for a half-ounce and an ounce, is very easy to use. And having several means that you can combine multiple spirits without rinsing in between. They’re also superb for pouring measured drams of precious Pappy Van Winkle. Use them for baking and cooking, keeping in mind that one-half ounce is a tablespoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Beautiful World Beside the Broken One
description: Nature is wide open for business. Here is the alternate world we need right now.
content: NASHVILLE — A two-week bout with flu turned me into a person I didn’t recognize — a hopeless, coughing, exhausted person. I lay in bed, phone in hand, skipping from news outlet to news outlet: refreshing, clicking, scrolling, scrolling, scrolling. The news was always bad, every update worse than the one before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: To Help Performers in Need, Funky Videos at Your Fingertips
description: The performer Taylor Mac and the playwright Suzan-Lori Parks have signed on to a video-sharing subscription service to raise money for New York colleagues in crisis.
content: Since the coronavirus crisis started, artists have posted songs, speeches and even Shakespeare sonnets online to cheer people up, while others have staged impromptu fund-raisers, like the one-night-only virtual return of Rosie O’Donnell’s talk show, which featured one guest calling in from the bathtub.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed Goes All In With Unlimited Bond-Buying Plan
description: The Federal Reserve will buy bonds as needed to calm markets, and will buy corporate debt in a series of emergency lending programs.
content: The Federal Reserve, determined to try to keep the spread of the coronavirus from devastating the American economy, rolled out a series of sweeping new programs on Monday meant to shore up large and small businesses and keep markets functioning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Republicans Add Insult to Illness
description: Greed, germs and the art of no deal.
content: If you want a quick summary of the state of play over fiscal stimulus legislation, here it is: Republicans insist that we should fight a plague with trickle-down economics and crony capitalism. Democrats, for some reason, don’t agree, and think we should focus on directly helping Americans in need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fiona Lowenstein
title: I’m 26. Coronavirus Sent Me to the Hospital.
description: Millennials: If you can’t stay at home for others, do it for yourselves.
content: I’m 26. I don’t have any prior autoimmune or respiratory conditions. I work out six times a week, and abstain from cigarettes. I thought my role in the current health crisis would be as an ally to the elderly and compromised. Then, I was hospitalized for Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Shechtman
title: Routine Medical Care May Break Down, and Covid-19 Is Behind It
description: We run a suburban medical office, not a front-line emergency room. But the lack of protective gear also affects us, and the people who need us.
content: Over 12 days ago, when I walked into my otolaryngology office in Westchester County, N.Y., my office manager gave me one high-grade N-95 mask. These masks are not supposed to be reusable, but somehow I had to make it last: We didn’t have any more. I later learned that we only had 25 protective gowns — likewise designed to be single-use items — for an office of nine medical specialists. When I saw a delivery of protective medical equipment in our building the next day, I assumed it was for my office. Instead it was going to the lawyers’ office down the hall. We are finally getting 20 more masks, but our shortage remains acute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick J. Lyons
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Epidemic-fighting experts explained what it would take for the U.S. to successfully stop the virus.
content: The wrangling on Capitol Hill over a $1.8 trillion package of measures to aid the stalling economy continued on Monday, after Democrats again blocked a version of the package that they said offered too little protection for workers and too much potential for abuse by big business.
source.name: The New York Times
